content: The report summarizes major legislative provisions in bills related to the reauthorization of the Federal Aviation Administration during the 110th Congress. Despite extensive consideration, only short-term extensions were enacted, delaying reauthorization to the 111th Congress. The report discusses key provisions and policy issues debated during the legislative process. The report outlines key legislative provisions related to FAA reauthorization during the 110th Congress, organized into six major program areas. It focuses on communicating legislative provisions without delving into specific policy issues, with separate reports available for in-depth policy discussions. The FAA reauthorization debate in the 110th Congress focused on funding authorization for aviation programs and the existing tax and fee structure that provides revenue for the aviation trust fund. The House passed the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2007 (H.R. 2881) during the first session. The Senate has not yet debated on H.R. 2881, S. 1300, and S. 2345. Revenue collections for the FAA have continued through appropriations legislation. The program was extended until June 30, 2008, by the Airport and Airway Extension Act of 2008. The Federal Aviation Administration Extension Act of 2008 further extended tax authorization and expenditure authority. The Federal Aviation Administration Extension Act of 2008 (P.L. 110-330) extended Trust Fund tax authorization and Airport Improvement Program expenditure authority through FY2008. The Continuing Appropriations Resolution for FY2009 provided funding for FAA programs until March 6, 2009, with increased funding for operations and a requirement to spend $1,099 million on aviation safety activities. The FAA began the legislative process to reauthorize funding in FY2008 with proposals for a new financing system, including user fees and excise taxes primarily for commercial system users. Bills were introduced in the House (H.R. 1356) and Senate (S. 1076) based on the FAA's proposal. The FAA proposal includes charges for commercial system users and excise taxes for general aviation system users. It also suggests modifications to airport revenues, such as increasing passenger facility charges and simplifying grant apportionment. Additionally, the proposal recommends management reforms like establishing an air transportation system advisory board and creating a commission for realignment and consolidation of FAA facilities. Proposed statutory language aims to integrate the work of the Joint Planning and Development Office. The FAA proposal aims to integrate the work of the Joint Planning and Development Office (JPDO) on the Next Generation Air Transportation System (NGATS) into ongoing planning and acquisition activities. It includes language to increase flexibility in delivering air traffic services, allowing airports and private entities to play a more direct role. The proposal also seeks statutory authority to control congestion at certain airports through market-based mechanisms like slot auctions and peak-period pricing. The Department of Transportation would study the appropriateness of a market-based system at New York's LaGuardia Airport (LGA). The FAA proposal includes measures to address congestion at airports through market-based mechanisms and funding for research on technology to reduce environmental impacts of aviation. It also recommends establishing a consortium for innovation in developing cleaner aircraft. The FAA proposal aims to introduce quieter and more efficient aircraft, limit the Air Tour Management Program to parks with identified concerns, and modify the Essential Air Service Program. Senator Rockefeller introduced the Aviation Investment and Modernization Act of 2007, which was favorably reported with amendments by the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. The reported bill S. 1300 proposes a four-year reauthorization with modest increases to FAA's spending levels. It offers an alternative user fee structure by creating the Air Traffic Modernization Fund financed through $25 surcharges on certain flights. Airlines and high-performance business jet operators would primarily pay the surcharge, exempting piston-engine powered aircraft. Over $400 million for FAA's Facility and Equipment account is to be derived from these surcharges. The bill S. 1300 proposes a four-year reauthorization with modest increases to FAA's spending levels. It creates the Air Traffic Modernization Fund financed through $25 surcharges on certain flights. Over $400 million for FAA's Facility and Equipment account is to be derived from these surcharges each year from FY2009 through FY2011. The FAA is given specific authority to collect these surcharges and impose sanctions on non-payers. Additionally, the Department of Transportation is authorized to issue up to $5 billion in obligations, repaid through revenues from the surcharges. S. 1300 proposes organizational reform for the FAA, creating a smaller oversight board with authority over planning, budgeting, and modernization. It includes $100 million annual increases to the Airport Improvement Program through FY2011. The bill S. 1300 proposes a pilot program at six airports to collect Passenger Facility Charges directly from passengers without a statutory ceiling on the amount charged. It also includes provisions for customer service improvements for passenger airlines, ensuring adequate food, water, and restroom facilities during substantial flight delays. Airlines would be required to provide consumer rights information and customer service policies on their websites. S. 1300 would expand DOT's consumer complaint investigations and require airlines to publish customer service and flight delay history information. It would also mandate agencies involved in the NGATS initiative to establish implementation offices and budget commitments. The bill extends $50 million annually to JPDO through FY2011 but does not establish a commission for FAA facility consolidation. S. 1300 does not establish a commission for FAA facility consolidation but instead creates the Air Traffic Control Modernization Oversight Board to review realignment recommendations. It includes provisions for involving the Federal Services Impasses Panel in cases of bargaining disputes and outlines a process for binding arbitration. The bill also addresses system capacity and safety improvements, such as runway safety and expedited rulemaking. S. 1300 includes provisions to improve runway safety, enhance airliner fuel tank safety, address pilot fatigue and rest requirements, implement NTSB recommendations for helicopter emergency medical service operations, regulate unmanned flight operations, and enhance wake turbulence prediction. It also aims to expand flights at Washington Reagan National Airport and address environment and energy issues through research and mitigation grants, as well as establishing a program to develop synthetic jet fuel from clean coal sources.
